sentence: Earnings season, the period of time when corporate earnings and results come at us in a flood, may be over, but that doesn’t mean that there aren’t some significant releases that cover the holiday period still to come.
Most companies end their quarters at the end of December and those have already reported.
Some, however, ended the quarter at the end of January or February and those earnings are coming out now.

Two large, well-known companies are scheduled to report earnings for the period that includes December tomorrow, and both could provide decent returns for investors who buy the stock before the report.

Both FedEx (FDX) and Williams-Sonoma (WSM) are trading significantly lower than previous highs, but a case can be that in both cases, with earnings expected, that represents value more than a warning.
Neither case is particularly complicated.
FedEx, for example, is an obvious beneficiary of low oil prices and the extremely well documented general shift towards internet shopping that occurred last holiday season.
Rival UPS (UPS) beat expectations when they released Q4 earnings at the beginning of February and that stock has climbed around 8% since then.
There is really no reason to expect a different result from FedEx.
The highs from last summer may be out of reach, but with a generally more optimistic stock market any decent results could spark a rally back up above 160.
From a longer term perspective as well, FDX is a great stock to own.
Over the years it has become clear that it is an extremely well managed company and has a tremendous record of sustained growth.
Given those facts and the chance of an expectations beat tomorrow, the forward P/E of under 12 looks way too pessimistic.
The case for Williams-Sonoma is also one based on simple logic and what we know from companies that have already reported.
It became clear that retail in general was not the disaster area that many were expecting as the bulk of earnings results were reported last month.
Many retailers handily beat lowered expectations for the holiday season, but some of the best results came in two areas.
Luxury consumer goods did well.
Both Kate Spade (KATE) and Coach (COH), for example, did well.
That indicates significant spending on aspirational goods by those in the middle class, something that should benefit a brand like Williams-Sonoma.
The other area that pleased investors was home improvement.
Home Depot (HD) and Lowes Home (LOW) both responded positively to decent earnings reports and guidance.
With the housing market recovery slowing there is mounting evidence that consumers are spending increasing amounts on “nesting” - improving their homes and surroundings.
Given that dynamic and the aspirational nature of Williams-Sonoma products, the general trends seem to be moving in a direction that suits WSM.
Once again, the 52 week high of over $89 looks out of reach in the short term, but a 10 percent or so jump to around $65 looks distinctly possible in fairly short order.
The excitement that surrounds earnings season may be over, but that doesn’t mean that earnings have stopped.
There are still a number of companies reporting and both FDX and WSM look to present opportunities for investors tomorrow.
